title: R44392
content: The Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) covers 72.5% of the premium for eligible taxpayers to purchase qualified health insurance. Taxpayers are responsible for the remaining 27.5% of the premium. The credit is refundable and advanceable, allowing taxpayers to claim the full amount even with little or no federal income tax liability. To claim the HCTC, taxpayers must meet eligibility criteria and not be enrolled in certain types of health insurance. To claim the Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC), taxpayers must be in one of two eligibility groups: recipients of certain benefits under the Trade Adjustment Assistance (TAA) program or individuals aged 55-64 receiving payments from the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation (PBGC). TAA assists workers who lose their jobs due to international trade. The Trade Adjustment Assistance (TAA) program provides assistance to workers who lose their jobs due to international trade. Workers must petition the U.S. Department of Labor to establish the cause of job loss. If confirmed, they are certified for TAA benefits, including the Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) if they receive Trade Readjustment Allowance (TRA). TRA is a cash payment for workers in TAA training who have exhausted unemployment insurance. Trade Readjustment Allowance (TRA) is a weekly cash payment for workers in TAA training who have exhausted unemployment insurance. TRA payments start after UI eligibility ends, with a maximum of 130 weeks combined with UI. Workers eligible for HCTC can receive TRA or UI. Reemployment Trade Adjustment Assistance (RTAA) provides a wage supplement for workers aged 50+ who secure lower-wage employment after TAA certification, paying 50% of the wage difference for up to two years, with a maximum benefit of $10,000. Alternative Trade Adjustment Assistance is also available. Reemployment Trade Adjustment Assistance (RTAA) and Alternative Trade Adjustment Assistance (ATAA) provide wage supplements for workers who secure lower-wage employment after TAA certification. RTAA pays 50% of the wage difference for up to two years, with a maximum benefit of $10,000. ATAA is a wage-insurance program similar to RTAA. Eligibility for the Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) is limited to individuals who receive TRA, RTAA, or ATAA cash benefits. To be eligible for the Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC), individuals must receive TRA, RTAA, or ATAA cash benefits. PBGC benefits are available to those who worked for a firm with an insured defined-benefit pension plan taken over by the PBGC. The agency steps in when plans need to be terminated to protect participants' interests or if employers can't stay in business. The PBGC steps in to terminate pension plans to protect participants' interests or if employers can't stay in business. They use plan assets and insurance reserves to pay pensions to former workers and their survivors. Those receiving PBGC-paid pensions may be eligible for the HCTC if they are at least 55 years old but not yet eligible for Medicare. The HCTC program has limitations on eligibility. The HCTC program has limitations on eligibility for individuals aged 55 to 65. Those enrolled in certain health plans or programs like Medicare, Medicaid, or military health coverage are not eligible for the tax credit. The HCTC program has eligibility limitations for individuals aged 55 to 65. Those ineligible include individuals with Medicare Part A, Tricare coverage, incarcerated individuals, or those who can be claimed as a dependent. Eligible taxpayers can use the HCTC for health insurance covering their spouse and dependents. Children of divorced or separated parents are considered dependents of the custodial parent. Family members have the same eligibility restrictions as the taxpayer. Family members of eligible taxpayers can receive the HCTC for up to two years under certain circumstances. The tax credit can only be used for 11 specific categories of health insurance coverage. The HCTC can only be used for 11 specific categories of health insurance coverage, including COBRA, group health plans through a spouse's employer, individual health insurance, and coverage funded by a VEBA. The HCTC can be used for specific categories of health insurance coverage, including COBRA, group health plans through a spouse's employer, individual health insurance, and coverage funded by a VEBA. Other options are available in states with established plans, such as state-based continuation coverage, coverage through a state high-risk pool, and coverage for state employees. Coverage under state-based plans comparable to those offered to state employees, arrangements with group health plans, private-sector health care purchasing pools, and state-operated plans without federal financing must provide four consumer protections to qualifying individuals. Qualifying individuals are HCTC-eligible individuals with three months of creditable coverage. State-qualified health plans must offer four protections to qualifying individuals, including guaranteed issue, coverage for preexisting conditions, and equal premiums for all applicants. State-qualified health plans must offer four protections to qualifying individuals, including guaranteed issue, coverage for preexisting conditions, equal premiums, and similar benefits. Certain types of coverage are not considered qualified health insurance, such as accident or disability income insurance, liability insurance, and workers' compensation insurance. The Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) program offers various types of insurance coverage, including automobile medical payment insurance, credit-only insurance, limited-scope dental or vision benefits, long-term care insurance, and coverage for specified diseases. The program is administered by the IRS with involvement from federal and state agencies, such as the Department of the Treasury for advance payment and the IRS for tax return reviews. The HCTC program provides insurance coverage and is administered by the IRS with involvement from federal and state agencies. The IRS reviews tax returns for the credit, while DOL and PBGC help Treasury identify eligible individuals. State entities like SWAs and health agencies also play a role in providing information about benefits like the HCTC. The Department of Labor (DOL) requests State Workforce Agencies (SWAs) to send Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) information packets to eligible Trade Adjustment Assistance (TAA) beneficiaries. The packets include an HCTC eligibility certificate. The Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation (PBGC) also identifies potential HCTC beneficiaries and shares their information with the IRS. The IRS then sends program kits to eligible individuals for claiming the tax credit. Eligible taxpayers with qualified health insurance can claim the credit. The IRS mails program kits to eligible individuals for claiming the Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC). Taxpayers with qualified health insurance can claim the credit when filing their tax returns or receive advance payments monthly. The HCTC is refundable, allowing taxpayers to receive the full amount they are eligible for, regardless of their tax liability. Other tax credits do not affect HCTC eligibility. The HCTC is available to individuals with little or no tax liability, and it does not affect eligibility for other tax credits. However, choosing to receive the HCTC makes one ineligible for the premium tax credit under the Affordable Care Act. In 2013, 13,693 tax returns claimed the HCTC, totaling approximately $52.3 million. The HCTC data for tax year 2013 shows 13,693 tax returns claimed the credit, totaling $52.3 million. In 2016, 13,015 e-filed tax returns claimed the credit. Taxpayers must complete Form 8885 and provide proof of payment for qualified health insurance to claim the HCTC. The credit amount reduces taxes owed and is refundable if it exceeds the tax amount. The Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) is refundable if the credit amount exceeds the taxes owed. To receive advance payments, individuals register with the HCTC program and must be enrolled in a qualified health insurance plan. They receive an invoice for their share of the monthly premium, which is 27.5%, and send payments to the Treasury. Individuals send payments for their share plus additional premium amounts for non-qualified family members to Treasury. Treasury then sends payment for 100% of the premium to the individuals' health insurance plans.
